column4: We enjoyed this museum quite a lot. Highlights were the animal mounts and the history of the Yukon. Exhibit about building the Alaska highway was great, too, in honor of the 75th anniversary of this amazing human and engineering feat!
Family and everyone will enjoy. Tells the story of the gold rush with real artifacts, gives a real human touch to the whole story.
This place was worth the long drive! Very interesting place, packed to the hilt with interesting pieces from history. There is no museum in the world like this one. I really hope to return one day!
We visited this museum and found it very interesting .It had a lot of material and artifacts concerning the Yukon region .I would recommend this as a must see in Whitehorse .
This place has preserved the historical thing of the Yukon so very well. It is amazing to see the historical and cultural development of the Yukon

With time to kill we took a local's advice and went here. There are several types of galleries including: First Nation; Gold Rush; early twentieth century; Alcan Highway; pre-history. We were charmed by the thoughtful presentation of their exhibits and the staff member. You will gain a greater appreciation of the area you traveled so far to explore.
The museum is a great walk back through history. With several mock ups and scenes from the past. This is a must see for tourists or even locals at least once..

This Museum is good for young and old alike. It gives a wonderful overview to the cultural, historical and natural life of the area. Don't miss the gold rush galleries, we almost did. I wish we had had more time to spend there.

This museum is a wonderful example of community and territorial history. It's got a really great layout and covers everything of general interest from prehistoric to modern time. There's well written storyboards and interesting artifacts to get your imagination into the frame. I was fortunate to go in the off season and had all the time in the world and...
A great place to encounter Klondyke Gold Rush history. There were several samples of gold from the different creeks that were mined along with all different kinds of equipment to see,

I was looking for things to do in Whitehorse, and the MacBride museum was a great budget-friendly attraction. Lots of visual and auditory displays, and plenty of information cards to read. Really interesting history of Yukon's origins!
Museum details the history of the Yukon. Very well presented material; good stop to add into your walk around Whitehorse.
Really nice museum. Spent three hours could of spent maybe one more, if we read everything , needed to leave due to 3 hour limit on parking meter. Nice afternoon, history, worth the money. $10cad

I was lucky to go when there were few others there as I was able to take my time in front of exhibits and read/look at leisure. There is so much to see and learn about - well worth the visit! Don't forget to go to the outside exhibits as there is another building to go through. It was worth...
Very good overview of gold rush times with history, tools, etc. with a complete overview of animal life in that area.

I ove going to MacBride Museum event. They are fun, are about storytelling from first hand of people who have lived and experience the Yukon for quite some time. I enjoyed the feeling of cabinet of curiosity with all the collection material and stories of the north. My favorite permanent dispaly with Kate Carmack clothing. The museum will be under...

Visited for a few hours when I was in Whitehorse.I loved the section with the animals, it was awesome! because you can see the actual size of them (really close, not like in the animal preserve, which is also very cool).Small museum, not crowded with lots of historical stuff (common things for every day use)
worht a go. has the most on Yukon history as well as mining. of interest to all who would more knowledge on the Yukon
loved the old exhibits of local artifacts AND old autos and train, not so much the stuffed animals ,the RCMP cabin was great ,with old phones,telegraph.

The MacBride Museum is well placed in the centre of Whitehorse near the banks of the Yukon River. The museum tells the story of the history or Whitehorse through many permanent and special exhibits, including a 1898 miner's saloon. Admission is $10 which is very good value to get an understanding of the social history of the Yukon.

This museum is currently expanding and undergoing renovations but what is available for viewing is very informative. You'll find a good display of the wildlife of the area as well as the history of the city and the building of the Alaskan Highway.

This museum has great exhibits for a $10 entry fee. Actual gold fragments. Impressive display on northern animals including 8 foot high grizzly, wolves and polar bears. Had to admire the feather parkas and the beaded mukluks. Impressive work.
Beautiful gallery of art out front. Not exactly the most modern or eye-catching of museums, but lots & lots of genuine artefacts.
So much to see, you will get to know and understand wild life over 60 parallel, Aboriginal inhabitants history, Gold Rush times and learn to do gold panning and finally to enjoy Sam's Magee story
this laid back, well appointed collection of Whitehorse and Yukon history is guided by exceptionally welcoming and friendly staff. Great for adults, kids, and youth.

I really enjoyed my trip to this museum. There was so much to see in it and unfortunately I had to leave too soon to meet a friend at the airport. Otherwise I would have wandered around longer than the 1.25 hours that I spent there. My friend and I walked through and spent a lot of time reading about...

The MacBride museum has great exhibits and lots of informative plaques throughout the building. It was a great look at how the Yukon got its name and how it has evolved over the years. The different types of transportation and the gold found in the river systems throughout the territory. Very informative and very interesting. Worth a visit for sure.

Plenty of interesting stuff to see here, well worth the time to learn about the area, it really gives a good idea of what this place was like and how tough it was to live here.Good exhibits and well informed staff, very good.

The museum was packed full of antiquities and information of history of the Yukon area. The taxidermy section of the Canadian animals were so real real, you could think they really were! I liked the life sized model of the old saloon - unfortunately I couldnt get a drink there! However a welcomimg touch in the foyer was complimentary tea,...

Lived in Whitehorse for two years back in the late 60s and never went. Probably just as well that I waited because the improvements made it worthwhile. Nicely set up, although one part was undergoing renovations.
Most informative and well displayed exhibits about the rich history of the Yukon and Whitehorse in particular.
The artefacts are in good condition, the exhibits are well put together. All around this is a lovely museum with lots to teach visitors.

We went just after the end of "official tourist season". The place was still had some exhibits open but not all of them. What was open was interesting and I learned a lot, but some areas were locked up / inaccessible. Seemed to me that the admission fee was a bit much ($10 per adult) for what was available to...

Small museum filled with interesting artifacts displaying the Yukon Gold Rush days,Robert Service, the history of Whitehorse, and the Yukon Territory areas. Excellent tour guide, also. Easily worth a couple hours or an afternoon.

This is a great stop for a half day visit. They have a nice supply of artifacts with great pictures and labels. There was a special program that day which was a presentation given by man who does dogs led races. He did a nice presentation, had all his equipment and a dog. There is some large outdoor displays and...
There is information here I didnt know about. It is a very informative visit and beautiful displays. I enjoyed this tour

Visit Klondike Goldrush at its best. Family friendly museum with workshops and events all summer. Lots of historical artifacts relating to the beginnings of Whitehorse. Also....will be visited by HRH's, the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge at the end of September, who are bringing Prince George and Princess Charlotte!
The MacBride Museum is a must see. Staff was very informative, exhibits provide complete insight into the history of Canada.
We did the Macbride museum visit on a rainy day but well worth it. A good mix of animal, mining and NWMP exhibits. Tell many stories about the gold rush and of the development of the Yukon.

From the moment we walked in we were impressed. It seemed to go on and on with exhibits inside and outside.We enjoyed the reading of The Cremation of Sam McGee, as well as watching vintage movies of the NWMP.We even return to buy souvenirs in the gift shop. Would definitely recommend stopping here.

We stopped in at the MacBride on our first full day in Whitehorse. It was a great way to get to know our host city for the next 8 days. The exhibits were informative and really introduced you to this vast area. The reconstructed sets of period saloon, restaurant, grocer, barber etc.. were my favourite parts.I strongly recommend the...

My wife wanted to spend hours in this place as there's just too much stuff to see and read. There is a $10 admission fee and it is a self-guided tour, you can take as little or as much time as you want.Ho, and you can also pan for gold!

This is a great museum to visit at the beginning of a trip to Whitehorse or the Yukon, to get an overview of the history of the territory. It is worth timing your visit around the daily programming that is offered, including the gold panning demonstration and the walking tour of historic buildings in downtown Whitehorse. The museum includes exhibits...
Enjoyed touring the musing and attend a 'Wayback Wednesday' where they had a BBQ and 6 storytellers. Much better than just wandering through a museum
This is an excellent view of Yukon history. A very informative guide. Kids would like it. Looks small from the,front but is several buildings.
Very interesting artifacts. Very informative gold panning demonstration.Worth seeing. Very friendly staff.

A great, concise look into the past of the Yukon. Very informative, great pictures and exhibits.The only downside to our visit was that the lower level gallery was closed as they were updating the gallery.

This little museum is a worthwhile stop for anyone interested in either gold-rush history or northern history in general. I love looking at the displays of everyday life from the turn of the last century. I live in the Yukon, and am always happy when I have visitors so I can take them here. The location is convenient as it's...

Loved this museum! I think this was the best museum I've ever been to. We loved all the Klondike history, and although we didn't stay for the "panning for gold", we could see some gold flakes in the prepared pans that were waiting for that tour to start.We couldn't get over the size once you're in, and each turn,...

Which means we had visited quite a few museums in two weeks in Alaska and Yukon, large and small, focused or general. And several of them very good. So this one, touching about many topics, didn't really bring us a lot. And may be we were tired. Though we visited Beringia just after and loved it.I may have rated...

This museum is a Canadian Treasure. The collection is fantastic and the Staff really make your learning experience memorable. They were knowledgeable and personable. This museum is a "must-see" to capture the vibration of the Klondike.
This is definitely a must-see museum which comprises so many aspects of Whitehorse history - geology, ecology, gold panning, first nations, sports and much more!

It looks deceiving (a mishmash of low lying buildings all clustered together) but its power is in its thoughtful and creative exhibits and displays. Wow...loved the section on gold, the wildlife displays, Sam McGee's cabin and the history hall. Very well put together with super friendly young staff. Great to see local young folks working in such a capacity. Their...
The museum is very informative about the early days of Whitehorse and the gold rush. Really helpful to understand what it took to cross the Chilkoot or White Pass. Really enjoyed it.

The MacBride Museum of Yukon History is such a gem....don't miss it! So well done and a treasure. $10 to get in and so worth it. You can spend hours and still not see everything. Grew up in Wash DC around the museums and for 6 yrs worked at a state run art museum.....and the MacBride is a real treasure!...
Well worth the visit! The museum does a great job of portraying local history and has some good interactive event including gold panning demonstrations. A real gem.
Small but lots of history. We'll worth the small donation. Live entertainment on some evenings included in price. I would recommend this to others. A "must do" in Whitehorse.

Lovely museum highlighting local artifacts and history. There is a room with a bunch of real (but stuffed) animals -- bear, wolf, fox, moose, lynx, etc. -- this was fantastic! There is an opportunity to pan for gold. The exhibits are interactive and if you read everything, you would be there for a while -- there is lots of information....
The staff were great, very welcoming. The displays were ok but not my cup of tea, not Into the stuffed animals, but did enjoy the cabins and the building that housed the replica scenes.

Such and interesting place. There is a large collection of stuffed birds and animals from the Yukon, with informative details about each species.There are numerous displays in the museum which give great insight into,the go.d rush history and how life was back then.Worth spending a couple of hours to ponder and take it all in.

This museum is located right in Whitehorse, down near the river. It cost $10 to get in. There was certainly lots to see. Many artifacts were displayed. They had plaques that showed the Yukon's national flower, animal, etc. There were lots of stuffed animals on display. Sam McGee's cabin was in the outside courtyard, full of artifacts. They even had...
Very informative museum of Yukon history. I really enjoyed the write ups of the people who helped settle and develop the area. Really really well done. Well worth the time.
The stories give you an idea of the gold rush days. Many exhibits inside and outside. The Yukon mammals and birds exhibits is interesting. Also one can learn gold panning and keep the results.
Without a doubt, an attraction that should not be missed. The museum houses the most extensive collection of Goldrush artifacts and the best collection of Yukon fauna anywhere in the world.
A must see. The artifacts were well displayed and explained. Loved the Pierre Berton narrated documentary.
A nice museum with exhibits of the wildlife of the area as well as its history. Multiple buildings and some outside displays.

Our aunt worked at this museum for many years and we wanted to see it. Good selection of many aspects of the Yukon. We really enjoyed the exhibit of Canadian animals as well as the gold mining part of the museum. For an extra $5 you can pan for gold. Nice way to spend some of the day.

The MacBride Museum contains many aspects of the history of Yukon - the gold rush and Klondike, the First Nations peoples, the animals which inhabited the area, people who made a difference in the Yukon. I enjoyed the variety in the displays which included some interactive presentations. The staff was friendly and helpful, although our particular tour guide was not...

The MacBride is the central museum of Yukon history, and is thus virtually a must-see for first-time visitors. The collection is wide-ranging and well displayed, although a little sketchy in the First Nation area. But even though our group came well into the season, our guide was poor both in preparation (she was still reading from notes) and in presentation...

This museum was incredible. The historical displays were fascinating and the natural history and geological maps were an added bonus. The staff was very helpful and courteous and the gift shop was certainly appropriately stocked.
History of the Klondike and the people and animals who lived the land in this area. There is a lot to take in and knowledgeable staff to teach and help.

We loved the museum - it touched on all relevant aspects of the region's history, had great exhibits and friendly staff. They also have a game throughout the museum that was fun for kids and adults alike.
Loved seeing all of the animals they had on display. Also seeing the actual Sam McGee's cabin was a treat in of itself.

There is a lot to see and read at this museum. You'll see animals and many artifacts from the early days of the gold rush. We sprung the extra $5 and panned for gold. You get to keep what you find. The kid loved that part. Sam McGee's cabin is vey cool. You'll learn a lot about how Whitehorse and...
good Museum, good to get to know the area and learn about history of this great country. Canada should be really proud of this one.
Great museum, plenty to see! $5 will get you panning for a small gold nugget! Lots of Yukon history here.

This museum had a lot of great little exhibits. Since we were there during the summer, we got to experience some of their daily program such as the Sam McGee cabin, learning how to pan for gold and a tour of Whitehorse. Well worth the trip for these activities alone.
Terrific exhibits. We enjoyed a reading of Cremation of Sam McGee and we panned for gold. Lots to see. Especially enjoyed exhibit of local fauna.
we were walking by and seen this venue lots of history and very informative for young and old. They had a interactive part for Children..
Very impressed with the information presented in this museum. A good history of the area, display of wildlife of the area and other surprises in this museum. A must see while in Whitehorse.
This was a great little museum which covered so much territory. The $10 entry fee was made worth it by the display of Yukon wildlife alone. The specimens were beautifully preserved and displayed.

This museum had a wide variety of displays, about the gold rush, early life in Whitehorse including a cabin used by Robert Service, a boat that worked the Yukon River, and a wide variety of stuffed animals.

Lots of history to soak up when visiting the MacBride Museum. Friendly staff were on hand to answer questions. Don't go late in the day; you'll need lots of time to take it all in. A great place to visit shortly after your arrival in Whitehorse since the museum puts everything into context.
The MacBride Museum is chock full of interesting displays, giving an overall history of Whitehorse and area. A must stop in the city.
There is so much to see in the museum that I can't single out one thing, we visited it twice to cover all the exhibits.

My husbands grandfather spent much of his life in Whitehorse arriving in 1904. The staff were very helpful in directing us to areas where we would find information about him. There is information about the First Nation, the gold rush, early transportation, early communication and the RMCP.

The museum was small but well laid out. A lot of interesting artifacts. Most of them relevant to the Klondike gold rush. Samuel did a really good job of explaining the gold panning while doing it. Samuel explained the concept of how much money miners other people in the area would have made. The outdoor exhibits helped understand the era....

Lots of interesting Yukon history and memorabilia in a very easy to find location in downtown Whitehorse. Great exhibits on Yukon wildlife and the Klondike gold rush. You can even get lessons on panning for gold. There was a bus tour visiting at the same time we were there and the museum was not overly crowded.

For such a small city (30,000) Whitehorse has put together a very extensive collection of historical artifacts. This museum is light, clean, airy and is chock full of history. The exhibits are well organized, and the staff are very friendly and knowledgable. The entrance fee was nominal and well worth it. The tales of the Yukon, past, present and hopes...
Too bad they don't have enough funding to keep the telegraph cabin open more hours of the day. Other than that it was an amazing collection of artefacts -- particularly liked the "hair picker"!

This museum is loaded with information about the Gold Rush. Be sure to watch the movie downstairs showing Dawson City back in 1950's. We stayed for a special presentation from a descendent of an early settler, very well presented.Also for an added $5 you can pan for gold.Nice gift shop, admission to the museum for adults is $10,...
Excellent gold panning presentation, efficient system with map and signage, new building is fabulous
Museum located I the downtown area. Easy to walk to. Museum is well located. Items all clean well laid out. Museum is easy to walk through and see all the exhibits.

Though well rated, we were surprised by the good quality, the variety and the picturesqueness of the items exposed yet. A must if you want to understand the history of the Yukon, particularly the times of the gold rush. Dedicate it at least a couple of hours to see it all.
Worth the fee which is very reasonable - they have senior rates! The museum takes one back - far back - to the first settlements. Very informative and educational.

MacBride Museum in town. The log building doesn’t look all that big, but the inside is crammed with displays that cover the history and culture of the area from the days of the First Nations people to the gold rush days, to the building and growth of Whitehorse. There is a display of indigenous animals that is really quite an...
A true walk through the history of the north. The way of life, First Nations, gold rush and beyond is well covered and displayed.

My husband and I greatly enjoyed our visit to the MacBride Museum. We both enjoyed the displays about the early days (including the gold rush, of course!) and the pioneers of the area. I spent more time checking out the displays about First Nations people, while he headed into the wildlife section of the museum. Once I met up with...
Good representation of all things Yukon gold related. Learned a lot of history about the Yukon Territory that we didn't know. The displays were very well done and very informative.

As a young high school student I studied Robert W. Service and his Tales of the Yukon. the most famous being The Cremation of Sam McGee. Robyn did a great job of explaining the importance of Robert Service to White Horse and the history of the Yukon. During her presentation she brought the famous poem to life. After her presentation...

The numerous exhibits are soooo well preserved and displayed. Klondike history is presented here, at its best! Short video of Klondike era, artifacts, restored buildings, wildlife exhibit and so much more! Situated right by the Yukon River, in downtown Whitehorse, def one museum NOT too miss!

We were impress by this museum, which is much larger than it looks. The staff person was engaged from the moment we walked in. The exhibits were interesting and diverse. They had a little room for children to explore, which was much appreciated. We enjoyed watching the film, narrated by Pierre Burton. If you want to understand the Yukon and...
This was one of the best local/historical exhibits i have seen. Lot of things collected from old times and there are also some information about nature as well.
This museum is really quite enlightening. Has a very good selection of stuffed animals of the area. Even has Sam Mcgee's cabin from way back when. Lots of artifacts from that period of time.
This was a lovely look at life in the Yukon......before, during and after the Goldrush. Well worth the stop. You could spend between one and two hours.

While not a huge museum, you'll find plenty to keep you interested and engaged for at least an hour - more if you're willing to dig deep into its various historical and cultural artifacts and displays.The museum is well-laid with excellent information on the items on display. Of particular interest would be the natural history area with the taxidermy...

If you love learning about nature, if you love the wild history of the Yukon, and if you love panning for gold.....Your going to love the MacBride Museum!They have all sorts of wildlife to learn about and a great gift shop and you can even pan for gold!!!! So come down here and visit the MacBride Museum and...

I was really impressed with the MacBride Museum. The property from the outside looks like a ragtag group of old buildings, but the interior is thoughtfully organized and tastefully decorated. There a lot of information and they chose some great artifacts that bring to life the people, places and events of the past that made the Yukon what it is...
The MacBride Museum gave us a excellent history of Whitehorse and the Yukon. The young lady who ran the place was very informative and truly loved the area.

This Museum is jam packed with stories and items of historical Whitehorse and only costs $10 entry. Loved the displays of Gold Rush Décor and vintage items of the era. Sam McGee's cabin was both cool and creepy (looked inside the window). The display of regional animals was great to see - did you know bears have 5 fingers? never...
The things on display made the history of the Yukon come alive. Seeing how people lived and survived was very much worth the visit.
Great museum to learn about the history of the Yukon and its wildlife. We were there on a quiet day and had lots of fun dressing up in old clothes and interacting with the staff.

A very well presented overview of local history...covers Native peoples, wildlife, the goldrush and mining as well as local characters. In summer months I understand there are further exhibits outside that were closed in February. there was a program for children that was enjoyed by the 2 and 4 year old that I was with. Staff were friendly and very...

Enjoyed the old locomotive display immensely. As an ex telephone company employee I was very interested in the telephone and power display. The video presentation downstairs gave a an insight into the history of the Yukon and Whitehorse.

We arrived at 3:30, 30 minutes before closing, and were told by the woman selling tickets that it really wasn't worth our $10 to enter for 30 minutes. We said that we were leaving the next day but she insisted that it wasn't worth it. We decided to look in the giftshop and while we were there, a man came...
Wonderful location, nice displays. Very complete. When the gold rush played out and the miners stampeded out, they left behind a wealth of interesting stuff for our delight.
So surprised to have found this little treasure. Excellent venue to tell the story of the Yukon. The displays of the "days gone by" very well done. So glad we stumbled on this this little jewel.

Great museum showcasing the Yukon - gold rush, native history, RCMP, animals,etc. If you are staying at a downtown hotel, this is within walking distance. Walking around town is a great experience too. Grab a coffee at Timmie's or Starbucks and off you go!

The MacBride Museum will not disappoint! The displays in this museum are amazing and capture a broad range of Yukon historical information, artifacts, and quirky information. The location on Front Street/First Avenue is accessible from anywhere downtown and close to many hotels. There is decent parking around the museum, but plug your meter for two hours to start and plan...
Spent about 2 hours wandering the museum and the grounds. Well worth the admission charge. Very well thought out exhibits and great to see the buildings they've brought on site like Sam McGees cabin.

We spent a morning at the museum and were happy that we did. It is a good way to learn about the history of the Yukon and its wildlife. They also have a room filled with costumes of the region in which you can dress up. It is worth spending 2 - 3 hours here.
This museum is packed with fascinating artifacts. Everywhere you look there is an item of interest. There is a lot to see and the artifacts are very well displayed.

On arrival we were greeted then given a map to the museum. This place is jam packed with history. A good size display of animals, gold history, Whitehorse history, plus a bit more. Plenty to look at and a small gift shop.

If you are spending and time in the Yukon this is the perfect place to go to put it's history into perspective. There are also a variety of documentary type videos that they show on a loop. It's right downtown near the river so it is easy to get to no matter what your plans are in Whitehorse. There is...

This museum carries such a collection of Yukon history and wildlife that it's easy to spend 3 or 4 hours without being bored. When I left the Yukon in 1997 then had only 4 % of their Klondike Gold Rush artifacts on display, now they have 50% of them out including at wall size map made in 1896. It's a...

A beautiful animal presentation, great family exploration opportunity, many nooks and levels to discover. Don't miss the "new" Jim Robbs's section downstair it is full of interesting facts and artifacts collected by the well-known artist. You can easily spend 1-2 jours there with your kids.

I saved this till last and stayed ages, so much information all beautifully presented. see the animal display and be amazed , also the mountees cabin and the gold rush bar pan for gold, and see one of the original railroad engines I will always remember this little museum.
Wonderful wildlife gallery with great interpretive programs for all ages. Displays of early Yukon businesses and gold mining history. Large photo collection available for research. Nice gift shop.

Great spot to spend a few hours when the rain outside coming down in buckets. Saw Sam McGee's cabin and that made my day. Had to memorize that poem in Grade 5. The displays of the northern animals very helpful as one never gets that close in the wild to see the details. Nice giftshop too.
While Whitehorse may not have a lot of attractions per se, this museum would be a must see amongst a plethora of top flight stops. It really is a remarkable place, right downtown. Go see it. Really.

MacBride is a great small museum. The staff are very friendly, knowledgeable, and helpful. The exhibits are well thought out and presented, even the animals, which is typically not my favourite, were great. It is well set up and easy to navigate. I loved the Jack Robb (special) exhibit. Takes about an hour to go through and is well worth...
The entrance fee was reasonable and there were a lot of items having to do with the history of Whitehorse and Yukon in general such as gold prospecting, hunting, trapping, etc.

Given the size if the museum I thought I'd be finished in under half an hour but the exhibits were interesting and well displayed so I invested the time. As the museum is conveniently located in the heart of downtown it is well worth seeing.

This is a pretty cool museum with well curated displays. Animals are in a diorama display without glass protection, so please resist petting them. There is a touching room where all the skins are available to heft and inspect. There is a fun dress up room for those in search of a selfie. The lower level has a fun collection...
Typical of Yukon museums, this one is full of taxidermy. If you are offended by lots of stuffed wildlife, this is not your place.We did the gold panning which was fun and educational.

I thought that this Museum was excellent. You could easily spend a few hours on site, reading about the exhibits. It gives a good overview of the wildlife in the Yukon, the settler's lifestyle and the Yukon Gold Rush. Possibly the best museum that we visited in the Yukon or Skagway.
We thought we would be quickly in and out but what a surprise, we spent about three hours there. So much to see and do, don't miss it.

This is a museum full of delights for every age. Not only does it have great displays but it also has a really nice gift shop. You will find drawers full of rock samples from different areas in the Yukon and other places. The entire museum is a great educational tool for youngsters, but, don't tell them that! There are...

While on the smaller scale of museum sizes there is a lot to see behind its doors. There are exhibits both inside and outside the museum covering flora, fauna, Indigenous history, mining, as well as Western settlement history.It can take an hour to an hour and a half to see all the exhibits though possibly longer if you decide...
A nice attraction in downtown Whitehorse. Very knowledgeable docent made it interesting. Lots of history of the area.

This was one of our favourite museums in Whitehorse! There is really great history both of the Klondike Gold Rush, but also of the local wildlife. They were showing a movie downstairs with very rich history, it was definitely worth a watch!

This was a fabulous experience. The front desk staff were friendly and most helpful in assisting us with questions about other venues. The displays are comprehensive and attractively arranged. A wealth of information. The children's room is excellent. Something for everyone. Allow at least several hours.
Lots of displays that are unique. Girl Scouts thru the years. Gold rush photos. And awesome taxidermy of arctic animals. All is nicely displayed with sound and light enhancements. Visited July 2014.
great for kids with hands on....lots of animal species...films, gold panning....closed on monday after labor day.

Myself and my 80 and 85 year old parents enjoyed our visit to this museum. There are a lot of things to see in here. We were there the first week in September and found that many areas were closed off which was disappointing. Also, there was very limited staff so it was basically walk around and read what you...
My husband and I really enjoyed our visit here as there were displays showing the Yukon back in the Gold Rush Days, etc. One of the staff members talked about the history of Sam McGee.
This a small museum but well worth a visit. There are displays of things associated with mining as well as memorabilia from the gold mining era.

I think this is the best (man made) attraction in Whitehorse. I've been here twice and the second trip was filled with looking at exhibits I had missed the first time. Lots of local colour here, from stuffed animals to the Alcan pipeline to Sam McGee
Worth a visit. Smallish museum which gives you a brief overview of the history of Whitehorse and the surrounding area.

A highlight of our trip to the Yukon. We visited Sept 5th. This museum covers a lot of territory and was very entertaining. Our favourite sections were the history of Yukon town names, Sam McGee's cabin, the wild animals (nature), the history of electricity development (a personal interest) and the RCMP cabin. The young lady at the front desk was...

Great little museum with friendly, helpful staff. A highlight was learning the true story of Sam McGee, he of cremation fame. My only complaint was that we visited the week before Labour Day, expecting summer programming to still be going because their website still listed it,(including a historical tour of Whitehorse that we were looking forward to) but alas they...

Nicely set up, excellent descriptive information. Covers Whitehorse and Yukon history from first contact by Europeans with the First Nations to roughly the founding of Whitehorse as the capital (1950s) plus a bit of geology on the mining (gold and copper) districts and some excellent exhibits on wildlife and the First Nations.

A complex of buildings with wooden floors, etc. gives one a sense of the history of the area and its founding. Excellent, well labeled displays of wildlife and living in the early days of Whitehorse as well as an exhibit of the influence of the gold rush days.

The Museum affords a good introduction to the wildlife and history of the Yukon Territory. On display, you'll find virtually every example of YT wildlife nicely presented in a well designed gallery. Gold was a major item in defining modern history of the area and you'll find good displays of that challenging time, including an exhibit of an typical early...
Great info and artifacts devoted to understanding the development of whitehorse & the Yukon territory. There is an impressive taxidermy collection summarizing the common animals of the region.
A must see while in Whitehorse. The museum was much bigger and elaborate than expected. Great value!
This place gives you a snap shot if Yukon like of yore... You should make it a part of your trip. We live here and go every year... Its awesome
This museum was amazing! We paid a $5 fee and go to learn how to pan for gold. This included a demo, and our own pan with sand/gravel and a little chip of gold. Lots of fun even though it rained.
Although not too big this museum packs a lot of interesting artifacts from days gone by and staff will take time to expand on info for various exhibits

There is a good museum packed with all sorts of interesting artefacts pertaining to human and natural history. Our costumed host recited "The Cremation of Sam McGee" outside of his little cabin, way to Pascale.

Greeted by the cheerest young lady we met in a museum anywhere. Stephanie is a gem! History of locals and displays are brought to life. Gold panning on-site. Numerous artifacts and native beading and clothing exhibits. A must see

Enjoyed our visit here... Well worth the stop. Allow 1-2 hours. Tried gold-panning, which is offered several times per day (we went at 10:30am). Pans were 'salted' with a very tiny piece of gold which you got to keep, but for the $5 extra, it was interesting for the experience, albeit touristy!

I think I might have enjoyed this museum a little more if we had had unlimited time to peruse all of the items that are housed in this small museum. Every corner is filled to the ceiling with things and, truthfully, I was totally overwhelmed. I stopped listening to the guide after about 20 minutes because I just couldn't look...

Lots of things to see in that museum. Many animals on display. Lots of antiquities from the gold rush era. Well displayed.We also went on the walking tour (included in the price you pay to get to the museum) given by Pascale. She is so knowledgeable! Also a descendant from well known families that are part f the history...
Informative and very well laid out.Friendly staff.I thought it was well done on showing the real history of the Yukon and many tidbits that many would not know about the place.

Wow history overload. This was a great local find, with a lot of excellent exhibits. I love walking though museums and the rooms are set up to display the items as they would be and not just sitting in glass cases. There were schools groups visiting and I they were dressed in costume and tracing mystery items in the museum.

All sorts of odds and ends are brought together in This Museum to create a panorama of Yukon life from the Klondike gold rush to the present. You can try panning for gold, and there is also an interesting section on Yukon wildlife. Well worth a couple of hours.

I was traveling with my older brother who is especially interested in the Yukon region and the great gold rush days, so he found this museum most interesting. I liked it, too--and enjoyed seeing all of the taxidermied wild animals on display--those of the region. They also have a nice gift shop with a good selection of books on the...
A very interesting museum. Definitely worth the price of admission! We enjoyed learning about the history and seeing some cool exhibits.

Very nice museum. I wasn't expecting much, so I was pleasantly surprised by the quality of the exhibits. They give you a good overview of both the history and the natural history of the Yukon. I was glad I took an hour to visit.
Recent upgrades has improved an already good little museum.Great showcase of Yukon history. Well informed staff

This museum is almost opposite the Westmark Hotel and is well worth a visit. There is a short movie available in the lobby and then some good exhibition rooms about native wild life, life in the past and gold mining. As part of the admission price you can go on an historical tour of the town with a local guide....

I enjoyed the history from prehistoric/geologic to modern times. lt made me want to learn more about the Klondike gold rush times. But I was also surprised to see artifacts like an early Polaris snowmobile. I learned how some of the Yukon towns got their names and was surprised that many of them weren't even in existence until well into...
This is a must do on your visit to Whitehorse. Lots of exhibits very knowledgeable and friendly staff. Well done! keep up the good work.
We loved this place! So much to see on every level from movies, to exhibits to a live oration re Sam McGee!
Make sure you save time to enjoy the sights and sounds offered here. You will indeed get a realistic overview of Klondike 98

I was at this Museum with a group of girls aged 12 to 17. We had the best tour ever by a young woman named Steph, who is clearly knowledgeable - and passionate - about the subject matter. She has a Degree in Museum Studies, and our tour focused primarily on the role of significant women during the Klondike. She...

We enjoyed the museum. Try panning for gold! Great snapshot of Yukon history. Interesting exhibits, some interactive. Play some shuffleboard, learn about the wildlife. Also check out the Cremation of Sam Mcgee.

I'll begin with a disclaimer--the McBride largely show cases the history of the white occupation of the Yukon territory but it does that in an interesting and eclectic fashion in its many indoor and outdoor spaces. There is an informative and somewhat poignant movie about the Klondike Gold Rush in the front area which also houses a gorgeous rendition of...

We were traveling via RV and spent two days in Whitehorse. We had never been here but, of course was familiar with some of the history surrounding it. We found the Visitor's Cener to be very user friendly with plenty of parking and informed staff. One of the places we knew we wanted to visit was the McBride Museum. It...

This museum looks small from the outside but is quite deceiving. It is a very nice size museum with many exhibits including animals of the north, the klondike, poets and writers of the north. THey have some timed hands on acitivities for kids and adults such as panning for gold. It is a really informative and interesting museum. It is...

A very pleasant surprise. Good 20 minute overview movie. Excellent information on gold mining and early Whitehorse. Also good information in the Mounties. Excellent exhibits with good information. Highly recommend need a couple of hours to thoroughly enjoy. Reasonably priced.
My mom and her friend and I panned for gold (successfully!), thoroughly enjoyed the museum exhibits and appreciated the staff's attitudes and behaviours...Thanks!
Spent 1 1/2 hrs. Returned for another two hrs. So much to see. Very well presented and programs done well.

Since I had never been to Whitehorse (or the Yukon) before, I made the MacBride Museum one of my first stops. There are quite a few different exhibits to see and seeing and reading everything could take a couple hours.I was fortunate enough to watch a demonstration of panning for gold. The museum employee was very knowledgeable and answered...
This museum is wonderful. There is so much to see you can spend hours wandering. The staff are very knowledgeable and kind.

This museum had so much to showcase and tell about that you could spend a couple of days there easily! There was the animals and the native peoples of the area, as well as a complete history of the gold rush time and early settlement days. Really worth it!

The MacBride Museum is a great place to learn about the history of the Yukon. It includes a great wildlife display, Sam McGee's cabin, history of the gold rush and hundreds of artifacts. Well worth spending a couple of hours while in Whitehorse.

The McBride museum was much bigger and better than I expected it to be. There were so many artifacts that all tell a story...a story of how they lived in the far north so many years ago. I highly recommend everyone visiting Whitehorse check it out.
A nice surprise from the get go!The layout of the museum is different and historical with a true sense of the local wildlife and living conditions of the early settlers.

Many different displays about the gold rush and Yukon in general. Spend a couple hours immersed in our history. Small children will bore quickly as most exhibits are not interactive. Do not skip the basement!
We visited several museums while driving the ALCAN. We enjoyed this museum a lot. We learned a great deal. I highly recommend this place.

The MacBride Museum offers a variety of programs during the season, June to August. We are here in May before everything starts and the site is still worth while to see. Information about gold mining during the gold rush ( a period of only 1 year), the birth and growth of Dawson City, Yukon Mammals and Birds.

We really enjoyed all aspects of this museum...which provides reflections on many aspects of Whitehorse and Yukon human and natural history using different media A modest entry fee (around $10); gift store with interesting offerings.

I did not expect much from the outside of this museum but was pleasantly surprised by the exhibits here. The walk through the history of the Yukon was so interesting with a old time bar, ladies hat display, and other small rooms set up so you could imagine life a hundred years ago. The display downstairs of Jim Robb's antiques...

The MacBride Museum has a wealth of displays. This is quite a surprise because the building seems small and unimpressive from outside. I especially enjoyed the display of birds and mammals which can be observed at very close range and are not hidden behind glass as is common in many exhibits.I also enjoyed "City of Gold" a nostalgic film...
It is really little but it has a little bit of everything. The animals skins are available to the public to touch.

The museum was interesting with the information on the past of Whitehorse. It is always interesting to see how place were developed. I would like to visit in the summer when the outside displays would be more accessible.
Great museum lots of interesting artifacts only complaint is that we didn't have enough time to see it in as much detail as we would have liked. Staff was very engaged and helpful.

This is where I held my wedding. The reason I chose it is the fact that it is not stuffy, fun, interesting and filled with things to see and do. From dressing up as a Mountie or Can-can lady, feeling the fur of the northern animals, panning for gold, unique made in the Yukon gifts, creative displays and more. You...

they have a lot of objects from the Gold Rush era, showcased in small rooms so you can really feel the athmosphere of the old times. we also loved the animals part and the First Nation embroided clothes were beautiful

Very interesting look at the history of the Yukon, mostly after the Europeans arrived. Like most small local museums, they don't have enough room, but that makes it more fun because there are things to see everywhere.

We really enjoyed this little gem of a museum; the gold rush display was excellent and the local history was well presented and we enjoyed viewing the artifacts. There is a display of local wildlife and natural history including a display of rocks and gems. Sam McGee's cabin is there too! An hour or two well spent.

The McBride is a small collection of buildings and artifacts barely considered old by most of the world but very interesting as a representation of early days in Yukon. I've only ever seen one leather covered, decorated Chinese tea chest (college dorm trunk size) and they have two. It's easy to spend an hour or two here.

fantastic accumulation of yukon history and artifacts. great gift shop. extensive mounted wildlife. educational. informative. maybe too much detail and reading for youngest or younger children. have to be old enough to appreciate. and need take the time to take it in and READ displays. NOT techno/modern for younger crowd, but VERY interesting for those willling to make the effort.
A great introduction to the history of the Yukon. Was very nicely laid out and presented. Gift shop. Staff very knowledgeable and helpful!
We really enjoyed this museum and spent about 2 hours wandering around. Great insight into local history, natural and man-made.

Highly Recommended! If you've got limited time to see things in Whitehorse, and/or will be seeing only one museum in Whitehorse, this should be on your list.Excellent displays - take time to read the information provided and better understand what the Yukon is all about.Also be sure to see "Blanche" the Albino Moose!

not to be missed. This museum is well worth visiting, it will give you a really great prospective of the yukon's history. Great for all ages.A must visit for tourists and locals who will learn a lot of interesting facts about how the Yukon evolved.
Liked: Organized and thorough. Lots of information that I hadn't seen elsewhere. Very well done exhibits.Disliked: nothing, it's one of the best museums I've seen!

It's Whitehorse style! I think I only pay $10 for the entrance. I like the animals displayed inside the museum. Don't expect too much or compare it with big city museum and you will not get disappointed. But I like it and I think the fee I paid is worth it - at least as a support:) Am glad I...

As first timers to the Yukon, we were impressed by the amount of history the museum captured. The cabin off to the side contained a lot of exhibits from the gold rush era and really gave a feel for what it must have been like back then.The stuffed animals also gave insight into the wildlife present in the North....

Lots to learn, well laid out exhibits, really gives you a feeling for the heritage of the place. There is a little bit of everything here, both inside and out, never gets overwhelming, but you could linger a long time if you wanted to!

It seems I'm always saying positive things. Ah, well. We LOVED this museum. Lots to see. Very friendly staff. We were there in the winter, so not everything was open, but still lots to see. Nice little gift shop. (We recommend the playing cards with 52 different photos and factoids, but we bought the last two decks.)
I would say that this museum will give one the best history of Yukon in one visit . The musseum has years and years of collections and gives best historic view of whitehorse for sure.

Extremely well organized, well run and very INTERESTING!!Much of the museum is set up as an actual mining town, complete with miners tent, barber shop and saloon. The taxidermy is amazing as well.We spent a very happy two hours in this marvellous museum!

The museum is an easy walk for anyone visiting downtown Whitehorse. Plus it's open year round. It's located in the most historic area of Whitehorse with special free parking for tourists. Its displays and galleries provide a good overview of Whitehorse from the Gold Rush days forward. It was nice to see all the First Nations handiworks - specially the...
Great place to go and learn about the early gold rush and prospecting and how they lived as well as the local animals (if you can't see them live). Great service

The Macbride Museum is well worth a visit. It has some great artifacts and does a good job of explaining the history of Whitehorse and the Yukon. Terrific display of the wildlife that kids would probably love.It is a bit cluttered and some of the displays are dated and/or bare bones. They are upgrading parts of it, but an...

This museum is worth a visit and is reasonably priced. Lots of information and artifacts to view. Lots about the gold rush and early life in the Yukon. Display of various animals found in the area. Certainly worth the time.
The MacBride Museum is very educational and informative. It is worth a visit. There is a lot of historic information about Whitehorse, the gold rush and the many animals that live in the Yukon.

The main, original, building has an excellent display of the animals of the Yukon. Animals are all real and the taxidermy is well done on most. First Nations artifacts are displayed and a very interesting video plays continually, although oddly enough the video is of Dawson, not Whitehorse. Having already visited Dawson, we really enjoyed the video of Dawson of...

What better place for a gold rush museum than WhiteHorse? We've missed this on several visits to WhiteHorse, finally getting to go. The Pierre Berton video is available to watch in a comfortable room, there's a walkthrough with pictures and examples of city life of the gold rush, a locomotive, animals of the area and examples of gold mining plus...

The time & dollar value are certainly well spent when viewing this museum. The intergrated history of the "Gold Rush" and early "Pioneering" are well documented and displayed. If you do not have a lot of time to spare then this is one visit you should make as you find out so much about the Yukon.

This is a unique museum in one respect: It has a variety of historical displays that span a wide spectrum of subjects of early Whitehorse history. You can spend a lot of time seeing what you like here and you can skim what doesn't interest you for something that does pique your interests.

Wow we were so impressed with how much is carefully packed into this small museum. The exhibits are well done with good information. There is a variety of exhibits including a temporary exhibit and short video. The fee was very reasonable $10/adult $5/student. The boys played a bit of shuffle board while they waited for us to explore a bit...

I would recommend coming here if you are at interested in finding out how Whitehorse and area came about. They have beautiful and realistic displays and also have the Sam Macgee cabin on the property. You learn about the gold rush, animals in the area, people that were part of shaping the north and historical events.

A great place to start your tour of the Yukon.Sam Magee lived here: the real Sam Magee's cabin is on the property. An old RCMP cabin from the days when Mounties were not only cops but justices of the peace. An amazing array of taxidermied Yukon wildlife. God fever history. Historical slide show. A gigantic copper "nugget" that's five...

MacBride Museum is a must-see for anyone new to the Yukon and interested in its history. The exhibits go into great detail about individual Yukoners, historical events, and the territory's culture that give one a taste of the Yukon's charm.Unfortunately, the museum doesn't lend itself to repeat visits and little has changed since they renovated the museum in 2007....

Took my out of town friend to MacBride and we had a great time. Gold panning, new and interesting exhibits plus practically a private tour by one of the staff. Super friendly and full of great Northern stories. Also ran into an ex Yukon Commissioner giving a talk. Super interesting exhibits. Highlights are the Yukon animals room and gold panning,...

This museum is hands one. Darling log cabin where Sam McGee lived with his wife. Beautiful history of Robert Stewart who wrote poems about Sam McGee. Natural wild life animals are depicted in large size real life. I live that kind of stuff. There were some women's clothes and household items. Many stories about the pioneers who lived in Whitehorse....
A must see if in Whitehorse, staff was friendly,outside and inside exhibits are great,history for the 19 and 20 century.
Had a nice time at the museum. Friendly staff and great exhibits. We were lucky enough to have visited on Yukon appreciation day so it was complimentary. Kids area has great photo ops :)

Must see !! Extensive collection of artifacts and photographs. Sam McGee's cabin is there, complete with period artifacts. Late 19th century, early 20th century mining equipment complete with commentaries.

We enjoyed our time at this wonderful museum. It provides a great introduction to the natural history of Yukon, and to the amazing story of the people who have lived here. I liked that it is not all glossy and polished; like the area itself, it has a rustic feel which suits the exhibitions. I normally do not like stuffed...
A little expensive at $20 each, but worth a visit on a rainy day. Especially liked the gold rush history... but wasn't keen on the mounted animals!

I have been here three other times and was looking forward to taking my daughter there for the first time. Since my last visit nine years ago, the museum seems to have gone downhill. The great mining exhibit downstairs was gone and the outside building were blocked off by a private event they were staging. It was not worth the...

We had a neat experience of learning how to pan for gold!!! Actually found some. The museum is very well done and has a lot of gold mining artifacts. If you want to learn about this era this is a great place to visit.

There are many stories to tell, but this museum did not tell them well. It felt more like a warehouse of old stuff with every nook and cranny filled. I like a museum that takes me on a journey and ties the artifacts to place and time. It certainly was interesting to see what they had, just comes up short...
visited in a afternoon, personnel sympatic. I had a really nice visit. here is a lot to see and to discover about the Yukon.

What fun. This was our first stop on our exploration of Whitehorse. I was very impressed with the quality of the museum exhibits. Effort has been made to set up scenery behind the actual exhibit making a great camera shot. Sarah, our young tour person, was knowledgeable and friendly. I had so much fun and this is a great place...

Nice local museum that packs a lot of info and things to look at in a medium sized place. I usually breeze through these things, but actually stayed for about 2 hours. Well done. The staff should be proud of their little museum.

All you expect to know and learn about Yukon - you will find here. Geological maps and examples, life size stuffed wildlife, panning for gold stand, Native Americans or First Nations expo, Gold Rush history, even original jail, cache and locomotive... Good for start or to make Yukon summary :)

Worth visiting in Whitehorse. Gives a good sense of the Klondike gold rush with Sam Magee's cottage on sight. You can pan for gold but will only get a small flake. Many Yukon animals are stuffed and on display as well. Takes about an hour.

This museum was done extremely well. There is a section on the First Nation and a display of there beautiful handiwork. The next section was the wildlife. This was down very well also. The Gold mining section was especially interesting. This is a must when visiting Whitehorse.

This little Museum is well maintained and a wealth of Gold Rush history. It's well worth taking an hour or two to soak in some of the background and lesser known facts of our Territory. If you have been here before, go again as the displays are always changing and always interesting.If you haven't been lucky in spotting wildlife...

Good museum to spend some time and get to know Yukon's history, and specifically Whitehorse's history. The scenarios they have help you to imagine what would it be lo live there during the gold rush. You can see all the types of animals you can find in the wilderness of Yukon. It's a must go!

So many small places have lost their history. They have saved nothing and if they have saved anything, they have nowhere to display it. I've been to many city museums in Canada, and considering the fragile heritage of the Yukon, the MacBride is amazing! They have the original telegraph office from 1900, a train which was built in 1881, artifacts...
Friendly, informative staff. Informative exhibition by Jim Rob - visual documentary of Klondike. Very cool!

This is a great site for locals and visitors to visit more then once. Great displays and interesting photos though out.Wild life display is very good and everything is laid out well through out several buildings.
Wonderful museum of Yukon history: First Nations beadwork and art, natural history, gold rush, life in the 1900s, and more. Great little gift shop, too. This is a must-see for visitors to Whitehorse.
Loved the large taxidermy mounts of big-game animals, gold-rush era museum pieces and historic artifacts. Ever seen a coat made from bird pelts? Incredible!
This multi-building facility houses a large collection of cultural artifacts and preserved wildlife.
I learned a lot and there are many exhibits. Would like to see the outdoor space developed more. I would highly recommend a visit!

You might walk past this and you would seriously miss the best of the history of the area.Julie is in charge of the reception and she will do everything she can to give you all the information on the history of this great town and its people. We found it a great way to find out about the Yukon...

Great overview of the town and area. We liked the animal displays as well as the period/location displays which showed what gold rush life was like. You could probably spend at least 2 hours here is you read all the display information.
This museum is worth the visit if you like finding out more about local places. It's only small but has got a bit of history plus some of the local wildlife
Full of interesting displays covering a wide range of topics, including gold mining, dog sledding. I am not usually a museum fan but I fully enjoyed this one.

A great museum that shows a lot of excellent historical material and history without the boring walk throughs you would expect with a "museum". Favourite part was the second building that walked through time and different eras of such a noble and rich history. If this doesn't suit your fancy, then the excellent staff will ensure you find something to...
was amazing with inside and outside displays. Good displays on dogsled racing, North West Mounted Police, early people....We were there for almost 2hrs..so much to see.

This is a great little museum, with First Nations history, natural history and exhibits of indigenous animals, mining samples, machinery, and all things Klondike. It is laid out in an interesting and informative way with even an opportunity to try a little "panning" in the summer months. Definitely worth the price of admission, be sure to pick up your "tourist"...

One of the best museums ever visited. We usually make it a point to visit local museums to learn more about the area visited. So much to see in such a limited space. Absolutely loved the Sam McGee cabin and story.

I give this attraction a 3 because of the opening hours!The museum closes at 4PM so you have to get there at least by 3 to see what they have collected.A longer opening time would be advantageous!Appears to be interesting from what I could see through dirty windows!
Worth the time. The people behind the front desk were very friendly and knowledgeable. Interesting things to see. I recommend it.

there is so much to learn about a life so far from what I know; this museum is a great testament to the history of the struggle and stamina of the people who came to mine for gold and the life they established

Definitely a place to visit to learn about the exploration of the Yukon. Nice exhibits with the great idea to learn about history by telling the stories of different people who had lived there. The basement displays everything about the Yukon Quest, a famous 1000 mile dog sled race.
So much packed in this not-so-small museum... Fascinating. Only minor criticism is that some of the equipment was not labelled, and I had no clue was it was!
Another gem in Whitehorse that gives you so much history. A must see on your visit. We learnt more about Robert Service and his impact on the north. It was a great education.

Lots of interesting stuff here - Sam McGee's cabin, lots of info about the Yukon's history. Staff were nice enough. My son panned for gold and was able to keep a few flakes (this is $5 extra) which he loved.

This museum is a collection of displays, diaramas and log cabins. There is in depth information about the gold rush and the early days of European arrival to the north. The museum is a must see for learning about the Yukon.

We held a reception for the Aborginal Peoples' Commission with Justin Trudeau in the 'courtyard' under the 'tent'. The staff was amazing. Peter got a personal tour of the museum by museum Board Chair Keith Halliday .... a truly memorable evening.

I have travelled around Canada a lot and I must say the mammal display is simply one of the best possible. Do you know what a wolverine looks like - NO? Well you can get just a couple feet from one and compare it to a wolf or marten or mink for that matter. Great exhibit with the critters -...

This museum covers the Yukon from prehistoric times right up to the present day. It has an impressive collection of stuffed animals of the area which is genuinely informative. It covers settlement of the area by prehistoric man. It covers the geology of the area. However given the history of the area most of the exhibits are related to the...

To really understand what these Sourdoughs experienced, see the movie in the theater first. The exhibits are interesting, although for the younger set, it is a lot of reading. Great wildlife exhibit, the presentation was cancelled due to being short staffed. Enjoyed the basement eclectic assortment of a little bit of everything and the gold exhibit in the back building...

The museum offers a free guided tour of the facility, but only once or twice a day. I'd highly recommend the tour, then go back through and look at things in detail if you'd like. There also appears to be outdoor activities for younger children available, but they were unattended on the day of our visit - plus we didn't...
I have been in the MacBride both to see exhibits and to attend meetings. It is a great place which has character and one should see Jim Robb's Colourful Five Per cent show.

A great little museum with a wide variety of displays, including a varied collection of stuffed animals (who's eyes follow you around the room!), a tribute to the Yukon Quest 1000 mile dog race, First Nation beaded work and a large display of gold mining memorablia and much much more. Gift shop offers treats for old and young. I really...
$10 was great value. They have a very modern, detailed history of Whitehorse area. Loved the stories on local characters and history. Looked like a small venue, but bigger than it looks.

The MacBride Museum is one of those small museums demand an entire day. They have a number of different exhibits, and they are all worth seeing. My only regret is not setting aside more time for the museum. I really enjoyed the exhibit on the history of the Klondike Gold Rush.

There is just so much to see in this museum, take your time and try to absorbe as much as possible. A few hours are needed to really get into this attraction.Our tour guide was fun and interactive, and they really made the museum come alive.The writings of Robert Service were really well represented, and the gift shop...
A friendly, quirky, homespun, thoroughly informative museum, which integrates individual stories with locations, place and environment, to give a real sense of living history. Delightful!
Lots of history of the pioneering days of Whitehorse and Yukon. Great models and replicas inside. Its a fun time with family for education.
it is an okay musuem but the woman giving the tour was so boring and grumpy i actually fell asleep on the tour

I am a museum professional by trade, so tend to view places like this with a more critical eye than most. For me, the standard of interpretation within this museum varied significantly. One of the first rooms we encountered was filled with stuffed animals, many of which had no labels indicating what they were (an albino moose? A wolf or...

The McBride Museum is a great example of good things coming in small packages. Each exhibit is carefully presented with a warm small town feeling. We had spent time walking most of 1st Avenue which parallel's the Yukon River before enjoying the exhibits and charm of this museum. The Yukon history is well presented and easily enjoyed. Don't forget to...
This is a very interesting collection of artifacts from all over the Yukon and different life styles and living conditions. This is a must see.

The MacBride Museum is in a great location, across the street from the Yukon River near the train station, and is a lovely, unpretentious place. The galleries and exhibits are very nicely done and the museums gets away from the simple glorification of the Klondike Gold Rush. The museum offers a broad view of Yukon history, with well-chosen and carefully...

take an hour and browse through the macbride museum and you'll get a overview of the history of this extraordinary area -- steeped in history of gold mining, fur trapping, milling, fishing, hunting...

Near the river, the museum provides great anecdotal history of the many - and there were many - characters who came up to the Yukon in the late 19th and early 20th centuries. The items on display are fascinating and are well displayed. Definitely worth a visit.
This is a great little museum with a ton of exhibits. Native artifacts, expertly preserved wildlife with all the major Yukon species and much more. Make sure you take the time to see this little gem.

There are lots of places to waste $10 in Whitehorse. This is not one of them. Probably the only Museum that provides the facts and not the mystique of the Klondike days, this centrally located, small museum is a must-do.

What a great little museum…it was like walking back in time.So many fascinating artifacts and exhibits.I would definitely recommend that you make this one of the must see places to visit while in Whitehorse.

My favorite part of this was the huge collection of expertly preserved animals. Many of these creatures one would never see in the wild, especially at such close range! Plenty of gold rush history as well.

Really, a very good museum. The Sam McGee cabin is excellent. The gift shop is small but has a very good eclectric selection. Terrific tee shirts and-- for just 45 cents, you can by a Whitehorse dog tag. High cool factor!. The info. about local artist Jim Robb is also top-notch. What a great visit this was!I highly recommend...

This is an extremely interesting and well presented museum. The staff are most helpful and obviously very proud of their museum. It cost $20 for 2 adults. Some outstanding displays and a lot of helpful history for those unfamiliar with the area. You can easily spend a couple of hours here.
I took a trip there when I first moved here and learned a lot! It is a quaint little place that I think everyone should see once.
Walking through this small but impressive museum opens your eyes to the live of the Klondikers and Robert Service. There are rooms of well cared for antiques set in their time period set.
I attended a wedding reception at the McBride and it was a very cool venue. I appreciated that the staff kept the gift shop open through the evening event and we got some cool souvenirs.
Well worth the time and money fantatic history on the gold rush
Very cool to see how the transportation has grown and developed over the years and how the Yukon has supported its own need for transportation so well
Nice displays and a glimpse of how the Yukon was settled.
For people interested in Yukon history, this is a great place. Nice staff, fun kids programs, fascinating exhibits. A little crowded but that's ok.
I loved this place. The exhibits were exciting, staff very nice, the movies outstanding. I bought an excellent video on the aurora.
We really liked the quality of the museum and the informative displays. A must see when visiting Whitehorse.
Nice size, and the exhibits are well maintained. Good for kids.
Great relics of the Yukon Past Well displayed and a comfortable tour. Enjoy entertainment every Thursday nite during the summer months.

This was an amazing museum, with a display of animals that included the largest moose I have ever seen in my life! It was an amazing way to see all the animals that call the Yukon home. It also contained historic artifacts of life in the Yukon, from First Nation depictions up to the Gold Rush life. I try to...

If you want to learn a little or a lot about the Yukon then MacBride Museum is an essential stop. I love the way the rooms have been done up to mimic a community during the gold rush. There is something to cater to any interest - a map of the creeks where gold is found, a Mountie outpost, a...
what a way to spend a couple of hours,I think its also open in the winter.i
Covers wildlife, geology, with emphasis on history -- reconstructed buildings, interiors, mechanical and cultural artifacts. Tries hard to convey life of a broad cross-section of Yukon residents.

very nice museum with lots of things to see and activities. It is a bit expensive $10/person, but they give you a little button that gets you back into the museum at another time, they say 3-4 days, but it is the same pin for everyone for the year, so you can use it when ever. I visited this museum in June, 2010. It does have a large display of numerous taxidermied animals, photographs and other artifacts, and some people will find it worth the $8 admission. I'm not much of a museum-goer, but during the rain, this was a perfect stop. What a wonderful surprise, and I'm so glad I didn't miss it. Thousands of well-documented historical items and photos, along withe great stories posted throughout the museum about Yukon pioneers.
